title: HACOR Score
description: Predicts non-invasive ventilation (NIV) failure in hypoxemic patients. HACOR stands for Heart rate, Acidosis, Consciousness, Oxygenation, and Respiratory rate. Best used in critically ill patients with acute hypoxic respiratory failure who require NIV, assessed 60 minutes after initiating NIV.

parameters.name: heart_rate
parameters.description: Heart rate in beats per minute

parameters.name: ph
parameters.description: Arterial blood gas pH value indicating acidosis level

parameters.name: gcs
parameters.description: Glasgow Coma Scale score assessing consciousness level

parameters.name: pao2_fio2_ratio
parameters.description: PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio in mmHg assessing oxygenation status

parameters.name: respiratory_rate
parameters.description: Respiratory rate in breaths per minute

result.name: hacor_score
result.description: HACOR score points (0-28 range) indicating risk of NIV failure

ranges.interpretation: Continue NIV with standard monitoring. Less than 20% risk of NIV failure. Reassess periodically and monitor for clinical deterioration.
High risk of NIV failure (>50% risk). Consider early intubation within 12 hours to reduce hospital mortality. Intensive monitoring and preparation for mechanical ventilation are recommended.

references: Duan J, Han X, Bai L, Zhou L, Huang S. Assessment of heart rate, acidosis, consciousness, oxygenation, and respiratory rate to predict noninvasive ventilation failure in hypoxemic patients. Intensive Care Med. 2017;43(2):192-199. doi: 10.1007/s00134-016-4601-3
Liu J, Duan J, Bai L, Zhou L. Noninvasive Ventilation Intolerance: Characteristics, Predictors, and Outcomes. Respir Care. 2016;61(3):277-284. doi: 10.4187/respcare.04220

Carrillo A, Gonzalez-Diaz G, Ferrer M, et al. Non-invasive ventilation in community-acquired pneumonia and severe acute respiratory failure. Intensive Care Med. 2012;38(3):458-466. doi: 10.1007/s00134-012-2504-9
formula: HACOR Score = Heart Rate Points + Acidosis Points + Consciousness Points + Oxygenation Points + Respiratory Rate Points
notes: Best used in critically ill patients with acute hypoxic respiratory failure requiring NIV
Should be assessed 60 minutes after initiating NIV for optimal predictive accuracy
Score >5 indicates high risk of NIV failure and should prompt consideration for early intubation
Early intubation (within 12 hours) in high-risk patients may reduce hospital mortality
AUC for predicting NIV failure is 0.88-0.90 in validation studies
Applicable to various causes of hypoxemic respiratory failure including pneumonia, ARDS, and COPD
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and overall patient assessment
Reassessment at 12, 24, and 48 hours may provide additional prognostic information
